item.title: Baldur's Gate 3 Reveals Its Rarest Achievements
item.description:
Larian Studios is celebrating the passionate Baldur's Gate 3 community by sharing some of the more obscure achievements players have achieved and the rare choices some have made in the massively popular title. Despite being over two years old, Baldur's Gate 3 continues to pull in tens of thousands of players daily, having become the go-to RPG for many fans of the genre.

Winning Game of the Year at The Game Awards 2023 and selling over 15 million copies, Baldur's Gate 3 has become of the most beloved titles of the past decade, finding commercial and critical acclaim for its visuals, storytelling, and vocal performances. While the game's final major content update was released in April, Larian Studios is continuing to maintain the RPG, with Baldur's Gate 3 getting a surprise patch in late July to address several performance issues and bugs. As thousands of players continue to flock to the continent of Faer√ªn to stop the Absolute from taking over the minds of the masses, the developers have shared some interesting tidbits about what the community has accomplished over the past 24 months.

Baldur's Gate 3 Devs Share Incredible Player Achievements and Rare Choices

In a new Twitter thread, Larian Studios shared some interesting details about Baldur's Gate 3 's most obscure achievements and the number of players that have managed to achieve them. According to the post, 1.1 million players have completed the game in Tactician Mode, while less than 4% of users have managed to defeat Gortash in Wyrm's Rock without triggering any traps. Only 1.82 percent of Bard players managed to earn 100 gold from playing music. Multiclassing in Baldur's Gate 3 is common, but an astonishing 2.30 percent multiclassed through every single class in one playthrough without seeking assistance from Withers.

Nearly half a million users have finished Baldur's Gate 3 in Honour Mode, which removes the ability to save scum and ends a run if all party members die in battle. In an even more unbelievable statistic, just over 4,600 players beat Honour Mode using only a Level 1 character. Larian Studios also shared some information about player choices, indicating that Wyll, Gale, and Shadowheart are the most respecced companions in the game. Additionally, since mod support was released last year, over 8,500 mods have been uploaded, with over 265 mod downloads.

While many players were disappointed to learn that Larian Studios wouldn't be working on Baldur's Gate 4 , Neil Newbon, the voice actor behind Astarion, recently shared his support for this decision. According to Newbon, the development team is ready to move on to something new, and he feels that the studio made "absolutely the right call." It's unclear whether Baldur's Gate 4 will be made by another studio, but for now, plenty of players seem quite eager to continue their Baldur's Gate 3 journey.

item.title: Kingdom Come Deliverance 2 is Better Than Ever - 6 Months Later
item.description: 6 months ago, today February 4th of 2025 Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 released on the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X and S, and PC. Quickly upon its launch it became the headline title for Game of the Year contention even though it only released in February. Since its launch though, it's gotten a ton of bug fixes, some new paid DLC expanding the world, and fresh modes to make the game even more realistic. So today on Game Rant let's look at Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, 6 months later.

item.title: Battlefield 6‚Äôs Approach to Matchmaking is a Blessing and a Curse
item.description:
Battlefield 6 is starting to earn a lot of anticipation, with the recent single-player and multiplayer reveal trailers for the project being very well-received. While the game's October release date might still seem far away, fans will soon have access to the full open and closed betas for Battlefield 6 , giving everyone a chance to see what the game is all about.

Of course, this also puts a lot of pressure on Battlefield 6 , which has to do a lot of work to move the franchise away from the criticisms of past entries like Battlefield 2042 . This has largely resulted in Battlefield 6 taking clear inspiration from fan-favorite games like Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 , which could extend over to the upcoming game's approach to matchmaking. DICE recently clarified some of the most important details regarding Battlefield 6 's matchmaking, addressing things like skill-based matchmaking and a server browser mechanic, leading to a mixture of reactions.

Some Elements of Battlefield 6's Matchmaking Go Against Fan Expectations

For better or for worse, discussions around matchmaking often dominate the communities of many modern competitive shooters. Major franchises like Call of Duty are great examples of this, with skill-based matchmaking (SBMM) being one of the most divisive and consistent issues that is seemingly here to stay. Many players see the launch of Battlefield 6 as a perfect chance for the DICE franchise to really stamp its mark against competitors like CoD , placing a lot of attention on how the game will approach SBMM for its own matchmaking.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 is expected to launch extremely closely to Battlefield 6 , which would be the first time these franchises have gone head-to-head since Battlefield 2042 and Call of Duty: Vanguard in November 2021.

DICE recently confirmed that matchmaking for Battlefield 6 will largely take into account server availability, player location, and ping, with SBMM also playing some role in who players are placed against. Understandably, this confirmation has been met with some disappointment, though there is a caveat that should make this news more palatable for opponents of SBMM. Reportedly, SBMM will play a lesser role for game modes with massive playercounts, like Conquest. This will, in theory, make SBMM less noticeable within Battlefield 6 's most iconic experiences, while having a higher impact on smaller-scale modes such as Team Deathmatch.

While the presence of SBMM in Battlefield 6 may end up being negligible, one other recently confirmed matchmaking aspect is much more surprising. It was recently announced that Battlefield 6 will not feature a server browser for its standard gameplay, which was one of the most highly-requested features for the game. Battlefield 6 's evolved take on the Portal game mode will possess its own browser, but core game modes will not have the same luxury.

Battlefield 6's Server Browser Absence Goes Against its Focus on Tradition

Of course, past games like Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 featured their own in-depth server browsers, which was an excellent way to allow fans to tailor their own in-game experiences. Battlefield 6 has already done well to take inspiration from these historic titles through things like smaller server sizes and maps, increased destruction mechanics, and more traditional classes. Despite this, the lack of an official server browser is a real departure from the freedom of choice that made the likes of BF3 and BF4 so enjoyable.

Battlefield 6 is still in a relatively early state, however, and there could be a possibility that a server browser at least gets partly introduced to modes outside of Portal in the future. It seems likely that the lack of a server browser is directly tied to the presence of skill-based matchmaking in Battlefield 6 , but players can take some solace in the fact that SBMM will not be as invasive or obvious in large-scale game modes.

item.title: Borderlands 4 May Be Co-Op, But One Vault Hunter Is a Solo Player‚Äôs Best Friend
item.description:
A core element of the Borderlands series has always been its cooperative play, with the original game even being one of the first shooters to feature drop-in/drop-out multiplayer within an open-world RPG structure. Solo play has continued to be perfectly viable throughout the series, but its cooperative mode certainly takes the excitement of looting and shooting up a few notches, especially for those playing with friends. Even so, the desire for rich single-player experiences has increased over the last few years, which means it's likely Borderlands 4 , despite its value as a cooperative game, will see many solo players joining the fray.

That doesn't necessarily mean that solo players will be at a disadvantage, however, as one of Borderlands 4 's Vault Hunters is actually perfectly tuned for solo play. Vex, the Siren, with her ability to summon minions and always have a companion at her side, almost turns the single-player experience into a cooperative one that doesn't require matchmaking. Add to that Vex's skill tree, which emphasizes survivability and sustain, and Borderlands 4 's new Siren is a solo player's best friend.

Borderlands 4's Vex Is Perfectly Tuned for Solo Play

Trouble Makes Every Encounter Feel Like Co-Op Anyway

There is more than one reason why Borderlands 4 's Vex is perfect for solo play, but one of her most distinctive features sees her summoning a minion to her side to assist her in battle. Trouble ‚Äî Vex's purple spectral cat companion shown in various trailers ‚Äî doesn't just help her passively during combat encounters, but he can also be commanded to perform specific actions that increase both his and Vex's effectiveness on the battlefield.

Having Trouble along for the ride essentially makes Borderlands 4 feel like co-op anyway, as it means that players can always have a companion at their side, even if they don't have any real people to play with. But perhaps even more than that, Trouble increases Vex's survivability and therefore her viability as a solo character. Trouble can help draw enemy aggro, for one thing, potentially splitting large groups of enemies in two by giving them an additional target to pursue. She's the only one of Borderlands 4 's new Vault Hunters who has a companion, and while it might still not feel like playing with friends, it's certainly better than actually going it alone.

Her Skill Trees Emphasize Survivability and Sustain

And Trouble is far from the only thing that contributes to Vex's survivability, as the Siren's skill trees seem to have been built around the idea of Vex being a great choice for solo players, with skills that aim to keep her alive and active on the battlefield. In fact, Vex may very well be one of the most solo-friendly Vault Hunters the Borderlands series has ever seen.

Her most notable skills for solo play in Borderlands 4 are Overprotective, Yowl and Bay, Blood is Magic, Blood is Power, and Overheal. With Overprotective, Vex and her minions gain an overshield with each kill. Yowl and Bay sees Vex's minions gaining max health, and commanding Trouble boosts Vex's gun damage for a few seconds. Blood is Magic and Blood is Power stack lifesteal and damage based on shields and kill streaks. Finally, Overheal allows both Vex and her minions to passively regenerate health when they are overshielded.

Again, there's no denying that Borderlands 4 , like every Borderlands game before it, has left plenty of space for those who wish to play it cooperatively. However, it seems that those who intend on playing it solo should look no further than Vex as their main Vault Hunter, thanks to her ability to summon minions to her side and skill trees that prioritize survivability and sustain.

item.title: PS4 Console Exclusive Game is Shutting Down Forever on August 31
item.description:
The PlayStation 4 console exclusive game Blacklight: Retribution will cease to exist starting August 31. The PS4 didn't exactly have a killer app at the time that it launched in 2013, but it did have some noteworthy games. Killzone: Shadow Fall was positioned as the big PS4 exclusive launch title, but other games like The Playroom , Knack , and Resogun also drew some interest.

Another PS4 launch title that drew some interest was the free-to-play first-person shooter game Blacklight: Retribution . Originally released for PC, Blacklight: Retribution was on the PS4 at launch and never released for Xbox or Nintendo platforms, making it a console exclusive for Sony's system. Blacklight: Retribution had some initial success and saw many years of support, but the PC version was shut down in 2019 due to dwindling player count numbers. The PS4 version was delisted in 2024, but remained available to play for those that already downloaded it.

When is Blacklight: Retribution Shutting Down?

Unfortunately, Blacklight: Retribution will soon be shut down on PS4 as well, meaning the game will effectively cease to exist. After Blacklight: Retribution was delisted, it was only a matter of time before it was shut down, and we now know that the game will cease operations on August 31 . From that point forward, there will be no official way for PS4 gamers to play Blacklight: Retribution .

Blacklight: Retribution is an old free-to-play FPS in a market that has long left it behind, but there is no denying that the game has some historical value. Blacklight: Retribution earned positive reviews at the time of its launch, and its status as a PS4 launch title makes it more important than many other games that have been shut down. The fact that it will no longer be available in any capacity is exactly why things like the Stop Killing Games initiative exist. Unfortunately, there's likely nothing that can be done to keep Blacklight playable, and so anyone interested in playing it - assuming they snagged it before it was delisted - will want to make sure they do so by August 31.

Blacklight: Retribution isn't the only PS4 game shutting down later this year. MMORPG Skyforge is shutting down on October 29, and there are a number of EA-published sports games on the chopping block for 2025 as well. Game shutdowns remain an unfortunate reality, and now that we're well over a decade removed from the launch of the PS4, it's likely that even more games on the platform will shut down.

Blacklight: Retribution
Released
April 3, 2012
